Legal_Issue: Does retrospective tax legislation violate Charter or Canadian Bill of Rights rights?
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, s. 7
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff claimed deduction after budget announcement disallowing such deductions
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to demonstrate violation of rights
Legal_Rule: Parliament may enact retrospective tax laws if language is clear; does not infringe s. 7 Charter or s. 1(a) Canadian Bill of Rights unless severe impact on security of person
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Tax Court of Canada to Federal Court
Grounds_for_Claim: Retrospective tax assessment violates constitutional rights
Review_Standard: Correctness or reasonableness (implied by trial de novo)
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Law was clearly announced; no procedural unfairness found
Applicant_Challenge: Validity of retrospective tax assessment under Charter and Canadian Bill of Rights
Defendant_Response: Assessment valid under clear legislative authority
Outcome: Plaintiff must pay assessed taxes without deduction
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Violation of fundamental rights by retrospective law
Applicable_Process: Statutory appeal process under tax legislation
Governing_Rule: Parliament has authority to pass retrospective tax laws with clear language
